question: Which observation would best indicate that a mountainous area was once covered by water?

content.source_1: Marine fossils are remains of ocean-dwelling organisms preserved in sedimentary rocks that originally accumulated under water.
content.source_2: In the described mountain outcrop, the marine fossils are embedded within an undisturbed limestone layer that is part of the mountainâ€™s bedrock stratigraphy.
content.source_3: Tectonic uplift can raise former seafloor sedimentary rocks thousands of meters, producing mountain ranges from rocks that formed beneath the ocean.
content.source_4: Glaciers can transport fossil-bearing rocks long distances and leave them as glacial erratics on ridges or summits, often resting atop bedrock of a different type.
content.source_5: Fossils found only in loose boulders or talus do not indicate that the local bedrock formed under water, because those rocks may have been transported from elsewhere.
content.source_6: The reported mountain fossils were collected from loose blocks on a talus slope and from a perched erratic resting on granite bedrock rather than from in-place bedrock layers.

answer: Marine fossils are found in mountain areas.
